subject: Ethics
title: CRISPR and Gene Editing Ethics
description: A quick, practical guide to CRISPR and Gene Editing Ethics.

hook.text: Scientists can now edit DNA like a word processor edits text. Delete a gene, paste a new one.

buildup.text: CRISPR-Cas9 made gene editing fast, cheap, and preciseâ€”opening doors that were locked for decades.

discovery.text: It could cure sickle cell disease, muscular dystrophy, and some cancers by fixing broken genes.

twist.text: In 2018, He Jiankui edited human embryos in China. The world condemned itâ€”the babies were already born.

climax.text: The tool is neutral. The question is who decides what counts as a 'defect' worth erasing.

punchline.text: We can rewrite life's code. Should we is another chapter.

quiz.question: Why did He Jiankui's 2018 experiment cause global outrage?
options: He edited genes in already-born adult patients
He used CRISPR to edit human embryos that were then born
He published his findings without peer review
